front: Who discovered the relationship between electricity and magnetism?
What observation led Oersted to discover electromagnetism?
back: Deflection of a compass needle near a current-carrying wire.

front: What is a compass needle made of?
What is electromagnetism?
back: The interaction between electric current and magnetic field.

front: Name one technology developed using electromagnetism.
Define magnetic field.
back: The region around a magnet or current-carrying conductor where magnetic force can be felt.

front: How is the direction of a magnetic field defined?
back: By the direction of the north pole of a compass needle.

front: From where do magnetic field lines emerge?
back: From the north pole of a magnet.

front: Where do magnetic field lines merge?
back: At the south pole of a magnet.

front: What is the direction of magnetic field lines inside a magnet?
back: From south pole to north pole.

front: Are magnetic field lines open or closed curves?
What does closeness of magnetic field lines indicate?
Why do magnetic field lines never intersect?
back: Because magnetic field direction cannot be in two directions at the same point.

front: Where is the magnetic field strongest in a bar magnet?
Is magnetic field a scalar or vector quantity?
What is the pattern of magnetic field around a straight current-carrying conductor?
What happens to magnetic field when current increases?
How does magnetic field vary with distance from the conductor?
Which rule gives direction of magnetic field around a straight conductor?
In Right-Hand Thumb Rule, what does the thumb show?
In Right-Hand Thumb Rule, what do curled fingers show?
What is another name of Right-Hand Thumb Rule?
What is the magnetic field pattern at the centre of a circular loop?
Does shape of conductor affect magnetic field pattern?
What happens to compass deflection when current direction is reversed?
How does number of turns in a coil affect magnetic field?
back: More turns produce stronger magnetic field.

front: Why does magnetic field add up in a circular coil?
back: All turns carry current in same direction.

front: What is a solenoid?
back: A coil of many turns of insulated copper wire wound cylindrically.

front: Magnetic field of a solenoid is similar to which magnet?
Describe magnetic field inside a solenoid.
What do parallel magnetic field lines indicate?
How is an electromagnet made?
back: By inserting soft iron core in a current-carrying solenoid.

front: Why is soft iron used as core of electromagnet?
back: It gets magnetised easily and demagnetised quickly.

front: Do all parts of a circular loop contribute to magnetic field?
What happens to magnetic field if current is switched off?
Who proposed force on current-carrying conductor in magnetic field?
When is force maximum on a current-carrying conductor?
back: When conductor is perpendicular to magnetic field.

front: What happens if direction of current is reversed?
Which rule determines direction of force on conductor?
In Fleming’s Left-Hand Rule, forefinger represents what?
In Fleming’s Left-Hand Rule, middle finger represents what?
In Fleming’s Left-Hand Rule, thumb represents what?
Is current direction same as electron flow?
Name a device based on force on current-carrying conductor.
Does magnetic field change speed of charged particle?
What produces magnetic fields in human body?
Which organs produce measurable magnetic fields?
How strong is body’s magnetic field compared to Earth’s?
What does MRI stand for?
What is MRI used for?
back: Obtaining images of internal body parts.

What is neutral wire also called?

Color of neutral wire insulation?

Current rating of high power domestic circuit?

Why is earthing necessary?
Where is earth wire connected?
back: To a metal plate deep in the ground.

front: How are appliances connected in homes?
Why are appliances connected in parallel?
back: Same voltage supply and independent operation.

front: What is an electric fuse?
back: A safety device that breaks circuit during excess current.

front: When does short circuit occur?
back: When live and neutral wires touch directly.

front: Which effect causes fuse to melt?
What is overloading?
back: Flow of excessive current due to many appliances.
